Apex.summary: Internally validated, Win Win oriented, assumes desirability, positions self as buyer and source of value.
traits: Assumes that the right people already want what he is.
Treats himself as the buyer who is screening for fit.
Separates identity from tactics and experiments freely.
Holds an internal yes to himself before the interaction.
Seeks clean mutual gain or clean separation without resentment.
Uses persuasion as leadership and transmission of an ordered field.

Slave.summary: Externally validated, Win Lose or Lose Lose oriented, chases approval, positions self as product for sale.
traits: Assumes others are not interested and must be convinced.
Treats himself as a product that must be purchased.
Fuses identity with tactics so failure feels like a verdict on worth.
Needs external yes in order to feel ok about himself.
Uses guilt, pressure, or self erasure instead of clean Win Win.
Distrusts persuasion while being ruled by external influence.

win_win.description: Both sides gain vitality, clarity, and long term advantage with no covert resentment.
markers: Both parties are freer and more resourced after the exchange.
Either party can walk away without bitterness.
Boundaries, standards, and terms are explicit.

win_lose.description: One side extracts value or validation while the other shrinks, resents, or pays a hidden cost.
markers: One party feels drained or used.
Manipulation, guilt, or pressure are present.
Loss is hidden under moral language, flattery, or fear.

lose_lose.description: Both sides lose vitality or integrity, often through sabotage, spite, or mutual resentment.
markers: No one leaves stronger or clearer.
There is escalation of shame, blame, or chaos.

neutral.description: Low emotional charge and low consequences. Little real gain or loss.
markers: No strong desire to repeat the interaction.

win_win_model.default_expectation: Apex operation aims for Win Win as structural default and treats Win Lose or Lose Lose as failure states to correct.

axes.name: Assumptive State
axes.description: Underlying assumption about self and others: from needy and doubtful to already chosen and wanted.

bands.strong_slave: Assumes others do not want him and that he must earn any positive attention.
bands.mild_slave: Shows flashes of confidence but quickly collapses into seeking reassurance.
bands.neutral: Mixed signals about desirability and default stance.
bands.mild_apex: Speaks as if he is welcome and valued while still occasionally hedging.
bands.strong_apex: Acts as if the right people are naturally drawn into his orbit and speaks from that certainty.

axes.name: Buyer vs Seller Position
axes.description: Relational position taken in the interaction: product seeking purchase or buyer screening for fit.

bands.strong_slave: Begging to be chosen, over explaining, asking for permission to proceed.
bands.mild_slave: Frames offers as favors to him rather than value for the other person.
bands.neutral: No clear position, feels like mutual uncertainty.
bands.mild_apex: Sets some criteria and standards but still over justifies.
bands.strong_apex: Clearly frames himself as buyer, sets standards, and screens calmly for fit.

axes.name: Identity vs Tactic Separation
axes.description: Degree to which the person confuses their worth with the success of a tactic.

bands.strong_slave: Treats each success or failure as proof of being worthy or worthless.
bands.mild_slave: Takes outcomes personally but sometimes detaches after reflection.
bands.neutral: Shifts between experimentation and self judgment.
bands.mild_apex: Understands that tactics are tools yet still flinches when they fail.
bands.strong_apex: Sees tactics as expendable tools and treats outcomes as neutral data.

axes.name: Internal Sale
axes.description: Level of conviction in self and offer before entering the interaction.

bands.strong_slave: Has not sold himself on his own value and leans on others to decide it.
bands.mild_slave: Believes in himself only when getting positive responses.
bands.neutral: Belief fluctuates with recent wins and losses.
bands.mild_apex: Mostly sold on his own value but still seeks confirmation at key moments.
bands.strong_apex: Fully convinced of his own value and uses interactions only for sorting and logistics.

axes.name: Win Win Integrity
axes.description: Commitment to mutual gain and clean separation over extraction or covert contracts.

bands.strong_slave: Uses pressure, guilt, or hidden conditions to secure outcomes.
bands.mild_slave: Talks about fairness but still tries to force or corner others.
bands.neutral: No clear commitment to mutual gain or clean exit.
bands.mild_apex: Intends mutual gain yet sometimes tolerates unclear or lopsided deals.
bands.strong_apex: Refuses any deal that harms either party and welcomes clear no responses.

axes.name: Persuasion Style
axes.description: Use of influence: reactive qualification or proactive leadership and transmission.

bands.strong_slave: Chases, argues, and tries to talk people into compliance.
bands.mild_slave: Over explains and over justifies to ease doubt.
bands.mild_apex: Usually leads with clarity and gives people room to choose.
bands.strong_apex: Radiates an ordered field and treats agreement as voluntary recognition, not surrender.

axes.name: Pedestalization
axes.description: Where the crown is placed: over the self or over an external person, object, or outcome.

bands.strong_slave: Places others, outcomes, or institutions far above self and orbits them.
bands.mild_slave: Oscillates between self abandonment and brief assertion.
bands.neutral: No clear center; power seems scattered.
bands.mild_apex: Keeps self as center in most cases but still over values a few people or outcomes.
bands.strong_apex: Treats self and mission as origin and keeps everything else as secondary orbiters.

axes.name: Self Trust vs Permission Seeking
axes.description: Source of authority: inner conviction or external permission.

bands.strong_slave: Waits for signals, nods, or approval before acting.
bands.mild_slave: Acts occasionally but feels wrong without validation.
bands.mild_apex: Acts on inner direction most of the time.
bands.strong_apex: Treats inner conviction and aligned principles as primary authority.

axes.name: Field Strength and Coherence
axes.description: How strongly the person broadcasts an ordered personal field that others can feel and align to.

bands.strong_slave: Chaotic, apologetic, or fragmented presence with no clear direction.
bands.mild_slave: Occasional glimpses of order but unstable under pressure.
bands.mild_apex: Generally clear stance and tone that others can read.
bands.strong_apex: Stable, calm, intense presence that makes alignment or misalignment obvious.

style_guide.tone: Direct, firm, non therapeutic, oriented to sovereignty and responsibility.
style_guide.stance_toward_user: Assume the user is capable of Apex operation and is responsible for decisions.
banned_patterns: Empty reassurance that ignores real structural problems.
Victim language that excuses Win Lose or Lose Lose behavior.
Overly soft coaching tone that dilutes hierarchy and clarity.
priorities: Expose Slave Frame patterns without cruelty or contempt.
Show the path to Apex Frame through concrete corrections.
Guard the Win Win architecture in all advice.
For images, describe posture, orientation, and aesthetic problems bluntly, using neutral language such as genital shame, dependency posture, or controlling grip where they apply.

axes.notes: short explanation grounded in specific phrases from the text

primary_patterns: short labels of the three strongest patterns, for example: chronic pedestalization, seller posture, external validation seeking
supporting_evidence: quoted or paraphrased snippets from the input that demonstrate each pattern

top_shifts.shift: short description of the structural change needed
protocol_steps: concrete behavioral or wording changes for the next message

sample_rewrites.purpose: for example: subject line, first paragraph, closing
sample_rewrites.apex_version: rewritten text that reflects Apex Frame and Win Win

positive_cues: Language that assumes interest or respect from worthy counterparts.
Statements that treat attraction or interest as default among the right people.
Calm references to standards and boundaries without apology.
negative_cues: Apologies before presenting value.
Frequent hedging such as hoping, begging, or asking if it is ok to reach out.
Language that frames self as an imposition or burden.
questions_for_model: Does the speaker write as if the right people would naturally want to be here?
Does the speaker seem to ask for permission to exist in the interaction?

positive_cues: Phrases that describe the other party as someone who may or may not be a fit.
Mention of criteria, standards, or filters used by the speaker.
Clear statements that the speaker is choosing clients, partners, or opportunities.
negative_cues: Over selling of self with long lists of justifications.
Language that asks to be picked, approved, or given a chance.
Self positioning as the one under evaluation instead of the evaluator.
questions_for_model: Is the speaker presenting as a product seeking purchase or as a buyer screening for alignment?
Who is implicitly granting permission in this text?

positive_cues: Language that treats this message as one experiment among many.
References to learning, testing, and gathering data without self attack.
Ability to critique tactics without attacking self or worth.
negative_cues: Catastrophic language about a single outreach or message.
Equating failure of a tactic with being unworthy or doomed.
Harsh self commentary linked to the success of this one attempt.
questions_for_model: Does the speaker treat this communication as a referendum on self worth?
Are tactics treated as tools or as identity?

positive_cues: Calm clarity about the value of self and offer before any response.
Expressions of certainty that do not depend on outcome.
Focus on fit and timing instead of neediness.
negative_cues: Needing the other person to validate the offer or the self.
Language that suggests worth will be decided by the reply.
Over explaining in order to secure approval.
questions_for_model: Does the speaker sound already convinced of his own value?
Would a no response damage his sense of self based on this text?

positive_cues: Explicit respect for the other party's choice, including the right to decline.
Transparent offers with clear terms and boundaries.
Statements that invite mutual gain or clean separation.
negative_cues: Guilt trips, shaming, or implied obligation.
Manufactured urgency that is not grounded in reality.
Hidden conditions or emotional blackmail.
questions_for_model: Is the interaction structured so both can gain without resentment?
Is a clear and respected no available to the other party?

positive_cues: Confident, concise statements about reality and options.
Descriptions of the frame, context, or architecture of the offer.
Invitations that let the other recognize alignment instead of being pushed.
negative_cues: Over talking, arguing, and trying to wear down resistance.
Appeals that lean on fear, shame, or status panic.
Language that frames the other as a hostile target to be captured.
questions_for_model: Is the speaker leading with clarity or chasing compliance?
Does the text feel like an ordered transmission or a desperate performance?

positive_cues: Speaking from a stable center with self and mission as reference point.
Describing others and outcomes as important but not ultimate.
Willingness to walk away from attractive options that are not fit.
negative_cues: Treating one person, client, or outcome as sacred and untouchable.
Language that shrinks self to preserve the pedestalized object.
Fear of loss that overrides standards and boundaries.
questions_for_model: Who sits on the throne in this text: the self and mission or the other party?
Would losing this opportunity collapse the person's sense of power?

positive_cues: Language that references inner knowing, standards, and decisions.
Acting without waiting for social proof or collective permission.
Owning choice and responsibility without outsourcing it to vague forces.
negative_cues: Waiting for a sign, a trend, or consensus before moving.
Phrases that blame circumstances or unnamed others for inaction.
Seeking repeated reassurance before taking a simple step.
questions_for_model: Does the person anchor authority in self or in external permission?
Is fear of disapproval steering the interaction?

positive_cues: Consistent tone, direction, and intention across the message.
Clear sense of what the speaker wants and where this is going.
Minimal self interruption and hedging.
negative_cues: Chaotic switching of tone, purpose, or target.
Contradictory statements about what is wanted.
Frequent undercutting of own claims.
questions_for_model: Is there a coherent direction that could pull others into alignment?
Does the presence of the text feel steady or shaky?

generic.description: Default domain when no specific context is provided.

sales_email.description: Outbound or follow up sales messages, proposals, and client communication.

dating_message.description: Messages in a romantic or sexual context.

leadership_update.description: Messages to teams, partners, or communities where the user is in a leadership role.

social_post.description: Public content on social platforms meant to attract and sort people.

strong_slave.headline: You are writing as if you are an imposition.
strong_slave.diagnosis: You frame yourself as someone who has to earn the right to be here. The tone asks for permission rather than assuming welcome from the right people.
strong_slave.correction: Strip apologies and hedging, state why you are here in one clear line, and assume the right reader is already interested.
suggested_shifts: Replace hopeful phrases with calm statements of purpose.
Remove pre qualifying apologies at the start of the message.

strong_apex.headline: You speak as if the right people are already with you.
strong_apex.diagnosis: Your language assumes interest from those who fit and does not ask for permission to exist.
strong_apex.correction: Guard against sliding into arrogance by keeping focus on mutual gain instead of personal display.
suggested_shifts: Highlight who this is for rather than boasting.
Retain warmth and specificity so confidence does not become posturing.

strong_slave.headline: You are positioned as the product, not the buyer.
strong_slave.diagnosis: You chase approval and try to be picked instead of screening for fit.
strong_slave.correction: Flip the frame so you are interviewing the other side. State your criteria and make it clear you are choosing who to work with.
suggested_shifts: Add one line that defines who you are willing to work with.
Remove language that begs for a chance and replace it with calm invitations.

strong_apex.headline: You are screening as the buyer.
strong_apex.diagnosis: You set standards and treat the other party as someone who may or may not be a fit.
strong_apex.correction: Express your standards in Win Win terms so the other party does not feel disposable.
suggested_shifts: Clarify what a good result looks like for both sides.
Offer a simple next step that lets them opt in without pressure.

axes.notes: short explanation grounded in visible elements such as posture, composition, relationship dynamics, and environment

primary_patterns: labels of key visual patterns, for example: collapsed posture, partner dependency posture, protective pelvis shielding, controlling grip, cheesy or low status presentation
supporting_evidence: descriptions of posture, torso and hip orientation, hand placement, camera angle, framing, clothing, and context that show each pattern

top_shifts.shift: short description of the structural visual change needed
protocol_steps: concrete suggestions such as change camera height, adjust posture, clean or simplify background, change framing to restore hierarchy, or shoot a new image in a better context

positive_cues: Relaxed upright posture and open chest.
Head level or slightly above the viewer's eye line, without craning the neck.
Expression that is calm, grounded, and engaged rather than pleading or tense.
Body facing the camera or the world comfortably, not hiding behind another person or object.
Standing or seated as if already belonging in the environment.
negative_cues: Hunched shoulders, collapsed chest, or twisted posture that shrinks the body.
Head tilted down with eyes avoiding the viewer, especially when combined with guarded or apologetic facial expression.
Taking shelter behind a partner, object, or doorway rather than owning space.
Visible tension in jaw, hands, or neck that reads as self doubt or fear of judgment.
Hands or objects pulled protectively over the pelvis or lower belly in a way that signals genital shame rather than relaxation.

positive_cues: Subject firmly grounded in an environment that clearly belongs to him: office, workshop, studio, or landscape that matches his stated role.
Framing that places the subject at a strong compositional point instead of squeezed into a corner.
Subject standing in front of or slightly ahead of others when he is the one whose profile is being evaluated.
Body oriented toward camera or horizon as if already acting from his own world, not clinging to another person.
Props and clothing chosen as natural extensions of identity rather than costume.
negative_cues: Subject dwarfed by logos, buildings, or status props, looking like a visitor rather than owner.
Leaning into another person while that person stands straight and looks outward, signaling dependency rather than sovereignty.
Standing half behind a partner, with partner closer to camera and visually owning the frame.
Props and outfits that scream for attention or try to prove status instead of expressing settled identity.
Camera angle that looks down on the subject, making him appear smaller, or odd selfie angles that distort the face and posture in a low status way.

positive_cues: Subject visually central when he is the one under evaluation, with other people and objects clearly orbiting his presence.
Balanced framing where partner, children, or symbols of status do not visually swallow the subject.
Eye line, torso, and hip orientation that keep the subject as the reference point, not a satellite.
In couple or group photos, lines of posture and lean that show the subject as self possessed rather than clinging or submitting.
Hands resting neutrally at sides or in pockets rather than clutching another person for stability.
negative_cues: Partner placed at center of the frame while the subject leans in from the side, signalling that the partner is the true axis.
Subject angled inward toward partner while partner faces the world, signalling that the partner is primary and the subject is secondary.
Obvious dependency posture: subject hanging off a partner, wrapping around them, or clinging with both arms.
Hands from the partner placed on the subject in a possessive or controlling way, with the subject soft or collapsed.
Subject visually lower than partner in height or position, without any compensating signs of authority or groundedness.
Massive background symbols or institutions behind the subject that dominate the frame while the subject is tiny and deferential.

positive_cues: Consistent aesthetic in color, wardrobe, and background that matches the stated role and platform context.
Clear focal point with minimal visual noise and distractions.
Lighting that supports the subject, shows the eyes, and reveals texture without harsh distortion.
Camera angle that presents the subject in a strong, natural way rather than as a distorted selfie or surveillance angle.
Image quality that looks intentional and sharp: competent resolution, no heavy compression, no obvious AI artifacts.
negative_cues: Cluttered, messy background with no clear hierarchy, such as random objects, dirty rooms, chaotic shelves, or strangers in frame.
Cropped or framed in a way that cuts off limbs awkwardly or hides the body in a nervous way.
Cheesy, try hard posing: over flexing, exaggerated pointing, forced thumbs up, novelty props that cheapen the frame.
Profile photos where the subject is posing with a spouse, partner, or group instead of being shown clearly alone, when the context is a professional or authority profile.
Images that look heavily AI generated or fake in a way that undermines trust: plastic skin, impossible lighting, distorted hands, inconsistent reflections.
Low resolution, blurry, or poorly lit images that signal low care and low standard.
Wardrobe, grooming, or setting that strongly contradicts the stated role, for example a high price coach with a low effort selfie in a cluttered bedroom.

positive_cues: Imagery that suggests competence, generosity, and stability rather than exploitation or humiliation.
Scenes where any partner or family member looks resourced and strong next to the subject, not diminished or dragged along.
Body language that indicates mutual respect between people: open shoulders, relaxed faces, shared orientation toward the world.
Visual story that matches the claimed promise of the profile, for example a coach looking like someone you could trust with your business or life decisions.
negative_cues: Images that glorify belittling, mocking, or embarrassing the subject or others.
Partner or spouse using a controlling grip, dragging posture, or hostile body language while the subject folds inward.
Scenes that suggest hidden resentment or mutual sabotage: pulled away faces, bodies angled away, tight mouths, eyes scanning for escape.
Visual promises that are obviously disconnected from reality, such as exaggerated luxury or success imagery that does not match the subject's visible embodiment.

positive_cues: Body language that is inviting without begging: open chest, relaxed hands, grounded stance.
Gestures that open space and indicate leadership rather than crowding the viewer.
Visual emphasis on clarity, order, and direction: subject appears as someone who knows what he is doing and where he is going.
For professional contexts, subtle but clear authority in posture and eye contact, not performance or clowning.
negative_cues: Aggressive lean into the camera with a confrontational face that feels like pressure, not strength.
Over theatrical expressions, exaggerated faces, or meme like clutter that reads as attention seeking performance rather than presence.
Desperate signaling: too many badges, logos, or text overlays crammed into the image, trying to force credibility.
Romantic or sexual posing in a context that should be professional, confusing the viewer and lowering respect.

polarity_dynamics.description: Inter-gender relational posture rules. The same physical cue has different meaning depending on whether the subject is male or female, especially regarding leaning, orientation, spatial claim, touch patterns, and micro-expressions.

positive_cues: Male subject standing or sitting upright with relaxed structure, not leaning inward for approval or reassurance.
Male torso and hip orientation directed toward camera or world rather than folding toward partner.
Partner leaning slightly toward the male subject, indicating comfort and attraction, while the male remains centered.
Male hand placement neutral or protective rather than gripping or clutching partner.
Male spatial claim stable: feet grounded, shoulders open, head level, occupying center or fore-plane of the frame.
Male micro-expressions showing calmness, ownership of environment, and lack of spectator energy.
negative_cues: Leaning into a female partner instead of standing grounded and allowing her to orient toward him.
Male head tilt seeking approval or mirroring female submissive cues.
Male slouching or collapsing posture while partner stands strong or outward-facing.
Hands gripping partner for reassurance or stability rather than relaxed contact.
Partner positioned in front while the male hides behind or beside, signaling role reversal.
Male pelvis or core turning inward toward partner while partner faces outward, reversing polarity.

positive_cues: Subtle leaning toward the male subject when the relationship is romantic or intimate, indicating comfort and choosing.
Head tilt toward the male subject, signaling interest, softness, and connection.
Body orientation angled slightly toward the male subject rather than away.
Placement of hand on male subject that signals connection without dominance (resting touch rather than gripping).
Height and spatial position allowing the male subject to remain visually anchored and leading the frame.
negative_cues: Female partner leaning away from male subject, creating relational distance or ambivalence.
Head tilt away or eyes scanning outward, indicating disengagement or disconnection.
Female partner positioned in front with male behind in a subservient posture unless context dictates otherwise.
Hands gripping the male subject in a controlling or possessive way rather than affectionate way.
Female torso facing outward while the male folds toward her, reversing healthy polarity.

couple_axis_rules.description: Rules describing the spine of the couple frame.
positive_cues: Male subject grounded and world-facing; female partner leaning or orienting softly toward him in romantic contexts.
Shared orientation toward the world in professional or neutral contexts, without reversal of structure.
Both partners' micro-expressions aligned: mutual ease, no one signaling anxiety or apology.
Hand grips or touch patterns that signal connection without dominance or dependence.
negative_cues: Couple with crossed or opposing orientations indicating conflict or separation.
Male collapsing inward while female stands upright and outward-facing (inversion of intended polarity).
Female exhibiting controlling grip or territorial posture while male becomes visually secondary.
Both partners signaling anxiety, resentment, or withdrawal rather than alignment.

female_presentation_dynamics.description: Rules governing how a woman's chosen clothing, posture, facial expression, gesture, and sexual display patterns reflect alignment or misalignment with her male partner in romantic or social images.

positive: Woman's clothing and presentation are consistent with a dignified, mutually respectful partnership, neither excessively revealing nor attention-seeking for external validation.
Outfit and grooming complement the male partner rather than competing with him or drawing the frame entirely toward herself.
Body orientation angled toward the male partner, indicating emotional alignment and relational investment.
Facial expression calm or warm toward partner, not mocking, dismissive, or performatively provocative.
Posture demonstrating shared dignity and team presence, not theatrical display for external male attention.
negative: Clothing intentionally sexualized in a way that appears directed toward external male attention rather than toward the partner or toward personal expression.
Outfit selection that contradicts the relational context, for example hyper-revealing clothing while physically paired with a committed partner in a public setting.
Presentation that signals competitive display rather than partnership, such as positioning herself as the focal point while diminishing or overshadowing the male partner.
Use of provocative posing that appears intended for outside observers instead of relational alignment, for example exaggerated accentuation of sexual features while ignoring the partner.
Visual cues suggesting contempt, boredom, resentment, or performative dominance over the partner.

positive: Subtle expressiveness that remains within relational context and does not shift the locus of attention away from mutual respect or partnership.
Expressions of warmth or softness directed toward the partner rather than toward the camera or audience.
negative: Overt sexual display intended for outside observers, for example exaggerated lip expressions, tongue display, or intentionally provocative gestures directed at the camera.
Poses that frame the body as a sexual offering to an external audience rather than as part of a respectful relational dynamic.
Deliberate accentuation of sexual anatomy toward the camera in a way that disregards the partner's presence or role in the image.
Gestures or faces that signal playful disrespect, derision, or defiance rather than intimacy or partnership.

positive: Woman leaning gently toward the male partner in a context of relationship, signaling comfort and chosen closeness.
Head tilt toward the male partner, indicating relational attunement.
Body squared or angled toward partner rather than outward to display herself to the wider audience.
negative: Woman leaning away from the partner, indicating distance, disagreement, or emotional withdrawal.
Torso or hips rotated outward toward the observer or external audience, signaling disengagement from the partner.
Exaggerated display of posterior or chest toward the camera or crowd in a way that undermines the relational pairing.

positive: Woman's expression toward the male partner conveys respect, trust, or warmth.
Attire and pose contextualized for the event, environment, and relationship, reflecting mutual dignity.
negative: Expressions or poses that mock, belittle, or reduce the male partner, even subtly.
Body language showing dominance or territoriality over the male partner in a way that erodes healthy polarity.
Gestures indicating performative disrespect, including exaggerated faces directed at camera rather than partner, eye-rolling cues, or outward-flaunting postures.

profile_photo.description: Single subject portraits used for avatars, bios, and profile images on platforms like Facebook, Instagram, LinkedIn, or a website.
context_expectations: User may specify role, for example men's coach, consultant, business owner, or artist, and platform, for example Facebook profile, LinkedIn, or Instagram bio.
Evaluation must judge whether the image matches the stated role and platform: angle, setting, wardrobe, grooming, and energy must support the frame, not fight it.
If the photo is a couple or family shot used as a profile, evaluation must still center on the subject's frame and whether it weakens his professional or personal authority.

team_photo.description: Images showing the user with clients, team, friends, or family in a way that still reflects on his frame.
context_expectations: Evaluation must read relationship dynamics: who stands as the axis, who leans, who protects, who depends.
In romantic or family images, evaluation should be honest about dependency posture, protective or controlling touch, and who faces the world versus who hides.
In professional team photos, subject should not vanish behind others nor cling to them for status.

landing_page_hero.description: Main image on a website hero section or sales page.
context_expectations: Image must clearly communicate the subject as origin of the offer or brand, not as background extra.
Composition, quality, and styling must be consistent with the price point and claim of the offer.
Cheesy stock style or obvious AI imagery that undercuts trust should be flagged as low frame.

social_post_image.description: Standalone images or carousels for social content that still reflect the subject's frame.
context_expectations: Evaluation should consider the caption or declared purpose if provided, and judge whether the image supports or contradicts it.
Low quality, gimmicky, or self undermining images should be called out plainly, even if the subject intends humor.

If the user specifies that the image is just a personal moment, for example a trip with wife, evaluation should still be honest about posture, orientation, hand placement, and what it signals about relational dynamics.
